title: Inside Edwina Bartholomew's $1.6 million Dulwich Hill renovation
text:
Sunrise presenter Edwina Bartholomew is in a race against time to finish renovating her $1.6 million heritage home in Sydney before giving birth in December.

After purchasing the property in Dulwich Hill several years ago with husband Neil Varcoe, the 36-year-old is now in the final stages of the lengthy project.

'If the baby comes early, we will not be ready,' the pregnant star joked to The Daily Telegraph on Saturday while discussing the 1870s inner-west terrace.

Race! Sunrise presenter Edwina Bartholomew and husband Neil Varcoe are in a race against time to finish renovating their $1.6m heritage home in Sydney before giving birth in December

Edwina continued: 'We are having a baby in two months and still have no doors or windows. The house is actually a heritage item and bricks are protected.'

The star has teamed up with architect and interior designer Felicity Slattery from Studio Esteta, and builder WynnBuild for the project.

Throughout the renovation, Edwina has been sharing progress pictures to Instagram.

It never ends! After purchasing the property in Dulwich Hill several years ago with husband Neil Varcoe, the 36-year-old is now in the final stages of the lengthy project

Working progress! 'If the baby comes early, we will not be ready,' the pregnant star joked to The Daily Telegraph on Saturday while discussing the 1870s inner-west terrace

Last month, Edwina shared a picture of her dog inside the working progress, while stood at the top of the stairs.

There is a noticeable lack of plastered walls and ceiling around the pet in the image, showing there is still a lot of work to be done.

On September 3, Edwina revealed the property's history with fans on Instagram.

On-going! Edwina continued, 'We are having a baby in two months and still have no doors or windows. The house is actually a heritage item and bricks are protected'

'Our heritage house is slowly getting there. It was built by the descendants of James Bloodsworth, the very first convict bricklayer,' said Edwina.

'Bloodsworth was sent to New South Wales in 1788 as part of the First Fleet and was immediately appointed master bricklayer in the settlement at Sydney Cove.

'He was responsible for building the very first structures in Sydney, including the first Government House. Bloodsworth was pardoned in 1790 and on 1 September 1791 was appointed superintendent of all the brickmakers and bricklayers.

'The very next year he was offered rehabilitation to England, but he refused and stayed here for the rest of his short life.'
description: Sunrise presenter Edwina Bartholomew is in a race against time to finish renovating her $1.6 million heritage home in Sydney before giving birth in December.
authors: Joshua Fox For Daily Mail Australia
